qas.question: What is the aftermath of infrequent errors during intracellular assembly of virus particles?
What is the result of bacterial adaptation of E.coli bacteria host and plasmid of another bacteria?

answers.text: conjugative plasmid integrates into the host bacterial chromosome

qas.question: Is conjugation a common bacterial adaptation?

context: <a0_0>Transduction of bacterial genes<a0_0/> by bacteriophage appears to be a consequence of infrequent errors during intracellular assembly of virus particles, rather than a bacterial adaptation. <a1_0>Conjugation<a1_0/>, in the much-studied E. coli system is determined by plasmid genes, and is an adaptation for transferring copies of the plasmid from one bacterial host to another. <a3_0>It is seldom<a3_0/> that a <a2_0>conjugative plasmid integrates into the host bacterial chromosome<a2_0/>, and subsequently transfers part of the host bacterial DNA to another bacterium. Plasmid-mediated transfer of host bacterial DNA also appears to be an accidental process rather than a bacterial adaptation.
